thread.title: Vanderbilt comes back to defeat MTSU
thread.title_full: Vanderbilt comes back to defeat MTSU

title: Vanderbilt comes back to defeat MTSU
text:
Vanderbilt comes back to defeat MTSU Aldo Giovanni Amato, agamato@dnj.com 11:09 p.m. CDT October 3, 2015 Oct 3, 2015; Murfreesboro, TN, USA; Middle Tennessee Blue Raiders linebacker Cavellis Luckett (24) celebrates recovering a fumble by Vanderbilt Commodores wide receiver Caleb Scott (9) (not pictured) with teammate Blue Raiders safety Kevin Byard (20) during the first half at Johnny "Red" Floyd Stadium. Mandatory Credit: Jim Brown-USA TODAY Sports (Photo: Jim Brown-USA TODAY Sports) 32 CONNECT 6 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
MURFREESBORO — Vanderbilt saved most of its offense for the fourth quarter as it came from behind to defeat MTSU 17-13. 
The Blue Raiders led 6-3 going into the fourth quarter and extended the lead to 13-3 as wide receiver Ed Batties caught an 18-yard touchdown pass from quarterback Brent Stockstill with 12:16 remaining in the game. 
Vanderbilt quarterback Johnny McCrary brought the Commodores to within three of the Raiders with a 39-yard draw play for a touchdown. That was with 6:14 left in the game. 
Commodore running back Ralph Webb ran 39 yards for a touchdown with 1:12 left in the game to give Vanderbilt the victory. 
The run game struggled for both teams early. 
The first half of the game began as a defensive chess match between MTSU’s offense and Vanderbilt’s stout defense, and neither team score a touchdown. 
A couple of Cody Clark field goals put up MTSU up 6-3 at the half and the first touchdown didn’t come until early in the fourth quarter. 
Quarterback Brent Stockstill found wide receiver Ed Batties for an 18-yard score on third down to give the Blue Raiders the deciding score. 
The Blue Raiders almost didn’t have an opportunity to score on that drive but caught a break after a roughing after a roughing-the-snapper call on Vanderbilt. 
Just a few plays later, the Blue Raiders hopped out to the biggest lead of the night. 
The Blue Raider defense held Vanderbilt quarterback McCrary in check for the most part, not allowing him to scramble for big yardage in the first half. 
MTSU’s defense flustered McCrary early, allowing safeties Alex Dale and Kevin Byard to record interceptions. 
Dale’s interception was the first of his career while Kevin Byard tied the MTSU school record for most interceptions, 17 in a career. 
The Blue Raider rush defense also kept talented Vanderbilt running back Ralph Webb in check holding the back to 4.7 yards through three quarters. 
Derek Mason’s offense could not find a way early to ground and pound it up the middle with one of the longest runs coming from wide receiver Trent Sherfield. 
Sherfield was the second leading rusher through a majority of the game as the Commodores failed to bust big runs against MTSU’s experienced front seven. 
MTSU will take its 2-3 squad to Bowling Green top face Conference USA rival Western Kentucky. 
Reach Aldo Amato at 615-278-5109 and on Twitter @Aldo_Amato
